texts.definition: Modifications to game items to make them more effective.
markups: <style="Definition">Modifications to game items to make them more effective.</style>
Equipment in game worlds provides benefits to those using them. <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> are ways for players to make these benefits greater by modifying the equipment.

Taking place in worlds where magic works, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style> make use of gems that can be set in equipment sockets and provide various bonuses. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Morrowind">Morrowind</link></style> have rules for players to use their skills in spells to enchant items, providing gameplay benefits to how these items work.

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%203">Fallout 3</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style> can improve the functionality of weapons in the game by installing items, e.g. scopes, silencers, and extended magazines.

<style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> are basically ways of giving players <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> so deciding on what <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> should be possible to improve through them; common examples include those related to <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style> or modifying the chance of <style="Link"><link="critical-hits">Critical Hits</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="critical-misses">Critical Misses</link></style> as special cases of this. Although <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> often are <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> - they are to be equip other <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> - they do not need to be <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>. However, giving <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> by modifying <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> is typically handled by <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style> since this is not a question of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Upgrading">Upgrading</link></style>.  Given that they are <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, e.g. gems, silencers, and scopes, most of the design decisions related to <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> are the same as for <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> in general. This includes who can use them, how they are acquired, etc. An exception when <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> do not function as <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> is when they are made possible through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, e.g. enchantment spells in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Morrowind">Morrowind</link></style> (although since <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Morrowind">Morrowind</link></style> requires ''soul gems'' and can thereby be seen as a combination of using a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Power</link></style> and a piece of <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>).

Common types of <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> which can be affected by <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> are <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="sockets">Sockets</link></style> are receptacles for <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style>, they can also be affected by <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style>, e.g. by them providing adding additional slots.

The action of installing <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> either can be one generally available to players or can be one governed by how <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style> works in a game.

<style="Link"><link="sidegrades">Sidegrades</link></style> are a specific type of <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> that rather than generally provide better <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> instead provide more specialized ones (in practice this means that they usually balance some type of <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Ability</link></style> that an <style="CurrentLink">Upgrade</style> could provide with some other type of <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Ability</link></style>).

While <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> typically are possible to acquire through gameplay, letting players get them through paying can be seen as a form of <style="Link"><link="pay-play">Pay to Play</link></style>.

Applying <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> are usually done in <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style> since it is there the <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style>, and <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> in general, are interacted with for most other purposes.

<style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> are a type of <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> that can provide additional <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> to other pieces of <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> through allowing the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Upgrading">Upgrading</link></style> of them. They provide players with a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> since the improvements can be done whenever they wish, but doing them are often <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> and thereby force players to make <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> decisions between different types of <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> modulate <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>, when these exist and the <style="CurrentLink">Upgrades</style> relate to the relevant skills.
